There are several screwable boxes here on Thingiverse, but I wanted to make one parametric so I could play around with it more easily. Now it's configurable, so you can play around with it even more easily.

You can set:
  • Height
  • Number of times the thread goes around the box. This is the number of full rotations that it takes to close or open the box.
  • Inner radius (mm)
  • Height of spirals (mm)
  • Thickness of box walls (mm)
  • Threads
  • Gap between inner and outer box (mm). Adjust to suit your printer.

description.text: Marvin is a wall (and foot) avoiding robot made from printed parts, an Arduino board, an Adafruit.com motor controller board, 2 motors (from Pololu.com), a distance sensor (from Pololu.com) and a battery clip (Radioshack). Video of the bot in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PfaEIkYA8fI The body, wheels and neck are parts designed specifically to fit what we already had on hand (with the addition of the Pololu parts since we lacked matched motors or a distance sensor). This bot was created as a mini-project of the MSU robotics group. (Midwestern State University, Wichita Falls, TX)

The printed and electronic parts are bolted together with small screws. Just drill a hole slightly smaller than what you have on hand and ABS self-taps nicely. We neglected to add spacers in the MarvinBody part, so we used some pre-made. We will print the spacers as part of the piece, next revision.
The MarvinCode.zip file contains the (very simple) processing code that runs on the Arduino board. It uses DC motors 3 & 4 and the sensor is on analog pin 0.

author: Zenpool

description.text:
This is a case for a "buck converter" high efficiency DC - DC converter. The ones I use are around $1 and are LM2596 based. They take in 4-35 volts DC and can output 1.23-30 volts DC (input needs to be around 3 volts higher than the voltage output so 5v in to 2 volts out would work, but 5v in to 4v out would not- input voltage would need to be closer to 7v in.
Search Ebay for LM2596. Try for an auction but dont pay more than $1. Make sure it looks like the picture of the board in the gallery!!
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4ninXMibkld

• Print it with >50% (.5) infill. Support not required (support is built in).

  • Break out the support on the inside of the case (needle nose pliers work well) and trim off support from the top.

  • Get a module from Ebay (or your favorite electronics provider) like here: http://www.ebay.com/itm/1-DC-DC-Buck-Converter-Step-Down-Module-LM2596-Power-Supply-Output-1-23V-30V-HE-/141313566024? or in qty5 here: http://www.ebay.com/itm/5x-DC-DC-LM2596-Power-Supply-Step-Down-Adjustable-Converter-Module-1-23V-30V-New-/281395701508?

  • Wire in your in and out (the hole for output is there but has a thin plug that you can cut out if you want in one end and out the other, otherwise just wire in and out on the lid).

  • Slide module into case with the voltage in end going in first, It is a tight fit! the board track may need cleanup to fit. There is a notch for where the potentiometer screw fits. Snap on the lid.

  • Apply your input power and adjust the pot through the hole in the case (it is labeled) to the desired output. This circuit will stay at the set voltage no matter what the input voltage changes to anywhere 3 volts above the set voltage up to 35v in!

  • Use it!

comments.text: This is exactly what I wanted and it came out great.  Thank you!
comments.author: JMA321

comments.text: Nice print! Your printer does a GREAT job!!  Sorry the adjust hole does not line up- that is a puzzler as your PCB looks like the ones I use.

description.text: Fraemes are your interchangeable, swappable, personalizable 3D-printed wonder-case. Designed by amazing artists from all over the world, the multi-part design (a 3D-printable insert, which you can pop in and out, and a rubber bumper) allow you to update your look as often as you please. If you haven’t already snagged your bumper or if you want more designs, you can get them on our website, here: http://www.fraemes.com/makerbot Have any questions? Just want to say hello? Don’t be shy - drop us a line at [email protected]

Fraemes are easily printed on your MakerBot using the high quality options in Makerware (ideally, use 0.1mm layer height, 40% infill, and no raft). You can use your favorite filament of choice (Fraemes are a perfect match for the MakerBot glow in the dark and photochromatic filaments). We've included a single file for your MakerBot Replicator and two smaller files for your MakerBot Mini. If you have any other questions, contact us at [email protected]

description.text: I tried to modify the sketchup bowden mount by dob71 and gave up after a few nights. I made this one in OpenSCAD. It's a work in progress until I add all the math to make it fully parametric. Video: http://www.flickr.com/photos/jaydmdigital/8366929968/

Edit the scad file as needed (I needed a different sized nut on mine), print, and enjoy. I will post the bowden cap scad a bit later after I clean up the file. Why try a bowden setup? It takes the mass and height of the Wades extruder and moves it to a non-moving portion of the printer (the frame). I use http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/118/135/=kz7az9 for 3mm feedstock. It has a 6mm outer diameter. I used some nuts I had on hand, but not sure what size they are. I am confident they and imperial though.

title: Filament Spool Holder Roller Stand Designed for 608Z bearings.

description.text:
If you do not feel like buying bearings check out this model: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001987 Filament spool holder / stand / roller for a very easy to obtain bearing, the 608Z ball bearing.
The space between the guides are 8mm since all my spools seem to be 7mm wide on the edge.
Initially I printed a holder that mounts on top of my printer, my printer has a glass bed. Someone on my printer support forum told me he did the same and gravity pulled a trick on him and now he had to order a new glass bed.
So I made this.
Added files with multiple parts included. Added optional screwmount with 3mm holes, can be drilled out of needed, just be careful. I would recommend only using one screwmount, that way you can use any spool size and the other one will probably keep itself in place. Please share your experiences in the comments. Please take a picture and share if you make one ;)

Print two of these.
Add 4 M6x25 or 30mm machinescrews and 4 M6 nylon insert nuts to hold the 608Z bearings in place. I guess you can use washers too if you like.
Now the 608z Bearing is something you should find in nearly every hardwarestore on the planet. If you don't like the thought of running down to you local hardwarestore just for some bearings you can always order some here:
http://www.dx.com/p/rapid-prototyping-bearings-for-3d-printer-silver-309048?Utm_rid=48516041&Utm_source=affiliate

description.text: This tools is used to un-jam a 1.75mm extruder. It will push material through a hot extruder. It can also be used to align the extruder during assembly. The rod is a standard 2mm bike spoke.

Print the part at 80% infill. Go to the local bike shop and ask for an old used bicycle spoke, they come in several sizes including 1.7 mm and 2mm I used a 2 mm. Cut the spoke in half with a hack saw,(do not use wire cutters, they will deform the spoke) file the ends to make them flat and remove all burs sharp edges etc. Glue the spoke in to the handle you printed and you are done.
The new tool can be used as a plunger for stuck or jammed filament that is down in the extruder. You can also use the tool to align the extruder you should be able to poke the metal spoke through the extruder and all the way down to the hot end. If you encounter resistance use the spoke to figure out how deep it is and find the trouble spot. There should be a smooth clear path from the top of the extruder all the way to the hot end if every thing is aligned properly. PLEAS NOTE 1.) Most bike shops will give you a few spokes for free, remember to thank them and tell them what your are doing with your spokes! ( it is good PR for our community and it is polite) 2.) If the hot end is on when you shove the tool in the spoke will get hot! be careful not to burn your self or melt things accidentally.

description.text: Fraemes are your interchangeable, swappable, personalizable 3D-printed wonder-case. Designed by amazing artists from all over the world, the multi-part design (a 3D-printable insert, which you can pop in and out, and a rubber bumper) allow you to update your look as often as you please. If you haven’t already snagged your bumper or if you want more designs, you can get them on our website, here: http://www.fraemes.com/makerbot Have any questions? Just want to say hello? Don’t be shy - drop us a line at [email protected]

Fraemes are easily printed on your MakerBot using the high quality options in Makerware (ideally, use 0.1mm layer height, 40% infill, and no raft). You can use your favorite filament of choice (Fraemes are a perfect match for the MakerBot glow in the dark and photochromatic filaments). We've included a single file for your MakerBot Replicator and two smaller files for your MakerBot Mini. If you have any other questions, contact us at [email protected]

I kept hoping someone would make these, and ... well, no one ever did.  I need them for building my RC stuff, and I'm out.  So...here they are.  12mm long, with a 3mm opening that fits M3 sized screws.  The screw end is a little long if you're going to end-to-end them...just clip them down with some cutters (I'll fix it later...pain in the backside to shorten a screw!).  I print at 50% fill...that way when you snip the screw...you don't flatten it too much.

title: C Cucumber
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A... B... C Cucumber! A key player joins us today as a part of BEACH WEEK! Download C Cucumber so he can hang out in your sandy environments. He likes to chill out in houseplants and on desks too!
By product of Jetty's Imagination, come to life!

We use replicatorG to slice and support most of our prints due to their overhanging nature. The slicer has a very effective support system that tends to leave minimal scars on the print itself, although it can print some things in a block of support material.
We find the best way to remove the print from the block of support material is with a butter knife and a small scraping tool. You can work the butter knife in between the vertical seems in the support structure and twist the knife. This loosens most of the support material which can then be worked around by hand to remove most of it.
Use the butter knife and scraper to remove the last remaining stuck bits.
We also have noticed that a low power butane torch can be good for cleaning up discolorations and fuzzies on the print. Be careful not to melt or leave the heat aimed at one point for to long
Warning : Be Careful cleaning your prints, don't burn or cut yourself. Do not let your children handle sharp things or fire. It's not our responsibility to prevent yourself from getting hurt cleaning your prints.

description.text:
9/3/2016: Updated shaft hole size. This version should fit much better. And if you still have fit problems, I've uploaded the .step file for easy editing with your CAD program of choice. 
(For real people, stop uploading just the stl file. CAD files (.step or .iges) are desperately needed in the 3D printing community for the purposes of easy editing! Seriously, let's put a stop to this nonsense. Upload your CAD files. We all know they exist. People need them!)
Easily slip this feed wheel onto your Printrbot feed motor shaft.   
Allows you to manually feed filament into the extruder by turning the wheel. Now you don't have to channel your inner Hulk and simultaneously mash down on the feed lever while using the other hand to feed the filament.   
Also provides a better visualization of the feed motor during printing. Plus, now your printer looks mesmerizing while it's printing!  
Comes with the Printrbot logo imprinted (no association with Printrbot other than the fact that it was designed to work with it).

I designed a few LEGO pieces here. The IPTs are included, so they can be easily edited. When slicing, scale the pieces 10x. If you wish for me to create a custom LEGO piece, please let me know.
The LEGO seen above were printed with PLA on a Type A Series 1 printer. I used 1.75 mm filament and .25 mm layer height.
I created the LEGO in Autodesk Inventor, using technical drawings from http://www.robertcailliau.eu/Lego/Dimensions/zMeasurements-en.xhtml.

This is a 3D printable Universal Joint! A U-Joint is basically a flexible axle. They are often used in automobiles. I printed mine in PLA with fairly standard settings. The model can also be scaled up or down to your liking.
YouTube Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NwT__Klpi40

Print "universal_joint_main.stl" at 5% infill without supports or raft.
Print "universal_joint_handles.stl" at the same setting as above.
Print "universal_joint_ball.stl" at the same settings just WITH supports.
Print "universal_joint_pegs.stl" at 50% infill on high resolution. After you print out the parts, place them in their correct orientation and position. From there, hot glue the pegs into the sphere; though the main pieces. Then, hot glue the handles on.

remixed_from.author: KipK
remixed_from.title: Mobius anti vibration mount for Pocket Rocket

description.text:
This is a mini 250 foldable tricopter dedicated for fpv.
Video: http://vimeo.com/105471252 Parts are available on Shapeways here RCGroups thread
If you feel generous enough, you're welcome to make a donation.
Yaw mechanic is protected between the center plate, the whole rear arm turn itself. ( http://youtu.be/u28iwAkf9TA ) 2 camera configuration possible:
  • FPV cam on top with Mobius between plates. There's a hole to access the mobius button from the bottom plate.
    This way you can tilt the fpv cam a bit.
  • FPV cam between the center plate and Mobius and the anti vibration mount on the top.
    Motor mounts are for Tmotors 1806 & clones ( I use RCTimer ones ) , or you can use the bigger one that fits for Sunnysky 2204 & co.
    Use 6" props with 3S or 5" with 4S.
    • You'll need small ESC, there's not much space on this little beast. Kiss esc are perfect for that. Here's a video of the yaw mechanics:

Most parts are printed with 0.2mm resolution.
Motor mounts & arm mounts needs supports.
I print the Yaw_arm_horn.stl with 0.1mm, it's better, but not necessary.
You can also print the center plates it works good, but it's better to cut them with cnc using G10 or Carbon.
You'll also needs:
  • 2x 19x10x7 bearings for the yaw axis
  • 1 micro servo ( the one I use is MKS DS450 22.5x10x23.5 mm )
  • some 10mm carbon tubes
  • M3 screws: 4x45mm , 4x30mm , 2x15mm
  • 10xM3 nuts + 2 threadlock M3 nuts.
  • 3.5x3.5 flight controller
  • 25x25 fpv camera or Mobius cam or booth.
    Cut 2x90mm carbon tubes for front arms, and 105mm for rear one if you use 5" props and want it minimal, or 2x100mm fronts & 1x115mm rear for 6".
    • Add a bit of tape on the end of the tubes to give some friction on the motor mounts and front arm mounts. This is quiet sufficient to fix them and will prevent breaking some parts in case of crash ( mounts will turn absorbing a bit of the shock ).

Affix a 3mm GT2 belt to anything. Back this up with a piece of aluminum for added strength.  Requires drilling through the belt, but that will make no difference in the applications relevant to the 3D printer world.  
2 hole version is for directly mounting to NEMA14 steppers (won't damage motor coils).
Anemometer: allows you the estimate wind speed though USB when used with a Yocto-Knob.

These are plastic parts needed to build an USB anemometer. These are meant to be used with a Yocto-knob ( www.yoctopuce.com/EN/products/usb-sensors/yocto-knob ), but any electronics able to count pulses, such as Raspberry PI or Arduino, would do as well. You will find here instructions for assembly. Details about electronics and programming can be found on our blog: www.yoctopuce.com/EN/article/how-to-measure-wind-part-1 This thing is assembled using screws and brass threaded inserts. This allows to assemble and disassemble it quickly and easily. Moreover, the final assembly is rock solid. Additional Hardware
You will need some non-printable hardware to build this thing.
- A 3mm led as powerful as possible, e.g. L7104SRC/J from Kingbright
- A 3mm phototransistor, e.g. : SFH 310-2/3 from OSRAM
- A 150 ohms resistor
- Electric wire
- A Yocto-Knob or equivalent
- A 3mm axle
- Two 3x10x4 stainless bearing ex: xirosÂ® B180 from www.igus.com
- M3 and M2.5 threaded inserts, such as BN 1036 - DIN 16903 B from www.bossard.com
- M3 and M2.5 screws
- M3 headless screws
- Optionally, a 16mm rod and a PG.M0.4GL.LN connector from LEMO. Tools
-Glue gun
-Various screw drivers
-Solder iron Mounting steps
STEP 1
Solder the wire on both LED and phototransitor, the short legs are the minus. Then glue them in the led holders, use a glue gun. STEP 2
Place the threaded inserts in all the parts with a solder iron, All are 3mm inserts, except the one for the led holders. STEP 3
Screw the LED holders on body top and bottom parts. Place the bearings. STEP 4
Force the sensor wheel on the axle and place it on the bottom part. STEP 5
Mount the body, make sure the sensor wheel turns freely with no friction, if needed use washers. STEP 6
Assemble the rotor, notice the headless screws used to lock it on the axle. You can make spacers from a brass 3mm tube, and force them into to the hub parts to make sure plastic wont bend when you tighten the headless screws. STEP 7
Assemble the body and the rotor. Optionally you can use the support. The support is designed to mount the anemometer on a 16mm rod and connect it with a PG.M0.4GL.LN connector Assembly is complete, now you need to wire it and to calibrate it. For more info on the electronics and programming, see www.yoctopuce.com/EN/article/how-to-measure-wind-part-1

title: Thin Universal Tablet Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a product I created based on a request of the design, but it didn't go anywhere, and I'm not going to produce it right away. 
So in the meantime, maybe you all can find some use for it.  It's pretty cool, and easy to print.  Doesn't take up much plastic, and you can use it with just about any tablet. Just stick it in your bag and forget about it until you need it.
That's what I do, but i have a butt load of tablets anyway. I usually use it for my Kindle Fire  HD, because I don't have a case for it, and just use it around the house.  Kindle Fire HD is great for watching Amazon Prime Vidoes, if you have it.

This stand can be used with pretty much any tablet. It's actually designed to be made from thin light metal, or a really strong plastic, but i print it in ABS and it works fine.
For those of you who know, i use a dimensions 3D printer, so i'm not sure how it will print on the other printers out there, so feel free to drop me a line and let me know.
All you do, is you twist it just a little to pop out the center part, and you slide that inside one of the two grooves, and BAM, you have a stand. 
Three positions, because you can then, flip it around, pop out the enter for the center, and slide them both into the grooves and and it's in the reclining position.
Have fun.

title: Parametric Wrench in OpenSCAD
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I needed a little wrench to tighten the M4 nylock nuts on my Mendel, so I designed a parametric wrench.

If you need a wrench to tighten M4 nylock nuts download the STL.  
Otherwise download the STL and modify the diameter value (flat to flat diameter of hex nut), thickness, overall length, and make any other modifications you want when generating your your own custom wrench.
This OpenSCAD version can also be made as strong (thick) or weak (thin) as desired. Simply modify the thickness and margin variables that I have at the top. There is also a variable for the overall length.
Otherwise download the STL and modify the diameter value to generate your own custom wrench!

description.text:
Just got my TAZ 4 printer and while I desperately want LED lights like I had on my old printer (makes viewing printing much easier and clearer) I did not want to start modifying my machine just yet (under warranty and all).  
So I took advantage of the modular mount they designed for the extruder. It has 4 bolts (see photo) that made a perfect place to slap some magnets on. Also the LED strip I happened to have was 24v (same as the system) and so I am hooking it up in place of the fan. I print mostly ABS so I removed the fan, if I ever print PLA I can just remove the LED's and put the fan back on in a minute or two.

The part prints easy with no support. You need 2 - 10mm x 3.2mm magnets (or close to that).  
Glue the magnets in the holes (use epoxy for best hold) and then you need a suitable 24v LED strip, mine was 100mm long by 10mm wide with a self adhesive strip on the back.  
You will need to remove the fan (sorry not for PLA users) and it got a plug from Mouser that fits the fan plug to power the LED's.  
You can then control the LED in software to turn it on or off and change the brightness (fan speed).  
The mount simply snaps onto the bolts shown in photo then push it up at high as it will go. The LED will be at 3o degree angle to light up the printing area.

comments.text: Awesome, I think I may splice into the fan connection,  Thank you so much.
comments.author: TahoeMike

comments.text: Be aware of the voltages. The hotend fan is only 5v while the material fan is 24v but it's PWM to change speed. Most of these LED strips are either 12V or 24V.
comments.author: TahoeMike

title: Rigidbot Dual Extruder Cooling Fan v1 and v2.

description.text: This is the cooling fan holder for a Rigidbot 3d printer with dual extruders.

This is the cooling fan holder I designed for my Rigidbot (big) Kickstarter kit printer with 2 extruders. This is my first 3d printer and my first attempt at designing a 3d printable model. I used 123D Design to create the fan holder and printed it using Cura. The settings used were 205 degrees (PLA), heated bed at 70 degrees, 100mm print speed, 2mm layer, Platform touching only line style supports. It was very easy to clean the supports and it works great so far.

title: In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious the Most Merciful

description.text:
Artistic Writing for The Names of Allah for Muslims
The Basmala (Arabic: بسملة‎ basmala), also known by its opening utterance Bismillah (Arabic: بسم الله‎, "In the name of God")[1] is the collective noun for the Islamic phrase "b-ismi-llāhi r-raḥmāni r-raḥīmi". This is the phrase recited before each sura (chapter) of the Qur'an – except for the ninth[Notes 1][2] – and is often translated as "In the name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful".[citation needed]
It is used by Muslims in various contexts (for instance, during daily prayer) and is usually the first phrase in the preambles to the constitutions of Islamic countries

description.text:
After using 2 months, the busing slips out during printing.
I hope the new one can fix the problem.

Slide your Jawbone Jambox mini into this case to protect it when traveling.
There is a front and back half, with a couple front decorative variants and a blank so you can add in your own design if you want.
The rear of the case has a clip and no-clip variant, depending if you want to have the speaker held in place with a spring-clip. This requires more tolerance on the printer though, so be careful.

This has been a work in progress, but I think I'm done tweaking the design.
This case is a two-piece model meant to be printed in halves and glued together. I tried several test prints before I was happy, and honestly, I don't know if it's possible to get this to work on the first try.
Be careful of warping— I probably should have added corner circles to hold the corners down, because a few attempts resulted in ruined prints due to bad warping. And be prepared to do a bit of post-print cleanup work to get this pretty.
Tested on a MakerBot 5th Generation and an Ultimaker2. The ultimate print pictured was printed on an Ultimaker2 with PolyFlex flexible material. Using flexible material gives a little more tolerance, and a little more bump protection. The tests on the MakerBot were a lot tighter fit ( almost too hard to get in and out ) and might need some tweaking to make the speaker fit a little more loosely.
You can also play around with printing one half in rigid and one half in flexible material, though I haven't tried this yet.
( This is an original work, built by measuring the dimensions of the speaker itself. It may need some tweaking to make the parts fit together on lower quality printers. )
( The pattern for "weird weave" was originally inspired by this reddit post ( http://www.reddit.com/r/pics/comments/1xwrig/60_hours_and_25_rolls_of_painters_tape_progress/) --and I drew up a pattern in illustrator based on this photo. I don't know the original source for this pattern )

comments.text: Try using SpaceClaim cad software, it would make your request a simple task after watching a few YouTube videos. It is free to download and use for 30days, long enough to make the necessary changes to the file for your speaker. Jawbone is awesome, so is SpaceClaim. It's by far the best/easiest cad software available. Good luck!

description.text:
I am now calling this project complete. If there is anything else that you would like me to add to this please feel free to message me.
Very complex customizable pendant with up to 432 outer rings and up to 43,200 inner rings. Getting this item exactly where you want it to be will be a long trial. I recommend getting a feel for it on the integrated customizer and then doing any serious setup within an Openscad editer. Please see below for a few tips for this item in Customizer.
Apologies in advance for a 840 line script just for a pendant. When using Customizer remember a few key things.
1.Move slowly!!!! This is an epicly large document and the Customizer is not streamlined enough to truly handle it.
2.Inner rings can only show inside of Outer rings. If for some reason your inner ring settings tell it to be outside of its outer ring it simply wont show.(You can however move an inner ring outside of an outer ring enough to only show small arcs of it!)
3.When creating a new Customized version of this item work with one outer ring at a time. Finish that ring before you add another. Each outer ring adds a huge amount of computations.
4.Take your time getting the feel for this while only using one outer ring. Moving between outer rings for full on custumizing can be very confusing.
5.You cannot not "twist" outer ring one. You would missalign the pendant loop.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/cFQIZ3GNGFe Sorry to anyone who downloaded the earlier file - It needed work and I accidently deleted it :(
Print with support.

description.text: Designed to fit Nalgene style widemouth bottles (including some CamelBak bottles and MSR Dromedary Bags) Optional gasket may be necessary to get a tight seal, it depends on the design of the bottle, materials used, print resolution, etc. The gasket should be printed in a rubbery material like NinjaFlex. I used Knotwork Woodwax to coat the inside of the cap (that's my sister's site). It's not designed for plastic, but I find it adds a water repellent and food safe coating. Print upright the cap upright, without support material. Update Oct 1, 2014: Added a new version this one should be easier to twist and is more likely to work without an additional gasket.

title: Gen 6 Deluxe PCB and Fan Enclosure

description.text:
Simply clips onto the profile of the Gen 6 Deluxe PCB on my Orca 0.4x but I guess this isn't a machine specific design.
It differs from it's mummy in that more of the electronic connections and wiring plus the fan is enclosed within.
It is fully printable without support. http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Print without support.  
Attach the 60mm cooling fan to the inside with M3 or M4 fasteners and clip on.  
I have included an stl file without the Gyrobot logo.  
I printed with 100% infill for strength and at 0.2mm layer height.  
Fashionably colour co-ord your printer even more plus help hide those wires.

comments.text:
Weak design, needs internal supports for strength - maybe thicker walls.
It also does not suit the generic gen6 board, the connectors are in different spots to the openings on the case.

Should have thicker walls and internal supports in the corners.

title: Sports Car - One piece print with moving wheels

description.text:
Sports Car model that prints on its wheels which will spin free once the designed in support is removed.
This model includes 'lateral support' so the axle ends flush with the side of the wheel. The support provides just enough support to allow the axles to build correctly so the wheels will spin freely once the support is removed.
Great example of what can be 3D printed... read instructions for more details.

On a Replicator 2 this prints well with 3 shells and 15% fill (so do not rescale to maintain clearances). No raft or support required as support has been built in already. Just break away the designed in support (refer support image to see what to remove) and gently free the wheels.
Once the wheels are free spray some silicone lubricant on the outside of each wheel and they will spin easily... another one part print most people cannot comprehend.
Note: Clearances may vary when printed on other 3D printers. Adjust the scale of the model to resolve so the support breaks away easily and wheels become free with minimal effort.

description.text: A printable X-carriage and extruder platform for the Printrbot+, featuring an integrated fan mount. Note that this does not include the bolt to hit the standard x end-stop switch, but works well with PolakiumEngineering's upgraded x-bridge: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31012 Print files for this Thing are now hosted at Youmagine

UPDATED: The Carriage (Carriage3a_fixed.stl) has been extended by 1mm to prevent the extruder motor from touching the Z-axis smooth rod when used with the standard wooden extruder. Print one X-Carriage and one Platform and you're good to go. The mounting nuts and bolts can be recycled from the existing laser-cut mounting. This was designed to hold the laser-cut extruder, so it should work with any other Wade's-like design. The main motivation for moving to a printed x-carriage was that the c-clips on the bearings of my lasercut carriage were rattling! The X-Carriage has my logo at the top of it, but you should be able to delete it from the sketchup file if you don't like awesomeness.

Akemi Homura's soul gem. Over 9000 hours on OpenSCAD.
Thanks hyperair and other #reprap members for the help. Haven't tried to print it yet. Made some upgrades, see 05 file. May be easier to print. This model is scaled at around 200% the size it should be, so if you want to print it at real size, scale it to 50% on your slicer.

As requested, the Flextensor 1.0 has been released!
This is intended as replacement fingers for a person with a wrist and palm, but no digits, most commonly the congenital amputation Amniotic Banding Syndrome (ABS). It lacks the elastics common to this type of assistive device. There are two main reasons for a mechanical extension system:
  • With elastic systems, the user fights resistance. Furthermore, the smaller an object the device grasps, the greater the resistance from the elastics. Mechanical extensors lend the user much greater strength, especially when grasping small objects (ie. those which require greater flexion)
  • Elastic systems only engage the flexors of the wrist, which can lead to unbalanced anatomy and repetitive strain. The Flextensor relies on both the user's wrist flexor and extensor muscles, which should be preferable from a therapeutic standpoint.

Here is a youtube video describing the Flextensor, its hardware, and how to string it up.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1Urkqoo09c&feature=youtu.be The only part here that needs to be printed with any support is the rod. 'TFRod' is a separate file, and should be printed separately, with support.
With a large print bed, or at a small scale, you can print just TalonFlexLeft or TalonFlex Right, plus TFRod.
If you have a smaller print bed, or need to print large-scale,
print:
TalonFlexLeftA, TalonFlexLeftB and TFRod for a left hand
TalonFlexRightA, TalonFlexRightB and TFRod for a right hand
All the parts are also available here individually.
I built this with my son in mind, a 20-year old with a large right hand and no fingers on his left hand. Tolerances have been calculated for a scale of 160%, about a men's large or extra large. If you print it smaller, joints will be tighter, and you will spend more time sanding it down. Also I print in ABS, so I need to count on some shrinkage. Abs shrinks as it cools, and then even more when I smooth it in acetone vapor.
So if you're printing in PLA and/or at scales below 160%, you are now forewarned. When I adjust this model for kids and PLA, I'll tweak the gaps. For smaller-scale prints, the narrower 'ppsnap4small.stl' solves the biggest tolerance issues for otherwise tight-fitting joints.
Here are written instructions for the Flextensor, and for the other wrist-powered devices I manage:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vJ-PtmFIwVkH40VfMw4m3pqWTApRizhIPzMrzEmNxDc/ Nylon webbing can be used to make straps, with rectangular rings and Velcro or double d-rings as a closure over the forearm.

Fair enough. I hope I can reconfigure my life over the next academic year to make this kind of work more central. For now, I'm just a high school language teacher and father grabbing what time I can to make these devices, hoping I might help someone. I'm frustrated with the limited time I have to spend on e-Nable work, and acknowledge that my mechanical prosthetics are under-documented. If you would be willing to fill in some of the gaps you see, I would be extremely appreciative. I really regard this work as necessarily collaborative; we each do what we can.
I designed this hand, but I didn't invent it. There is much collaborative work that was well-developed before I ever got involved. The mechanism linking finger extension with wrist extension I suppose I could call my invention. I did close my eyes and make that one up.

comments.text: What is the recommended material, temperature and infill ratio for this?
comments.author: JacobRusso

comments.text: I print this in ABS, at 96% infill, 5 shells. You could definitely reduce the infill for most of the parts here, but I wouldn't drop below 50%. Temp reads vary a lot printer to printer. Use settings that work for general printing. Tolerances make this function best printed at a scale of 140-165%. At a smaller scale, pins and hinges will be tight. For a small print, you can get the ppsnap4small proximal phalanges off the Talon Hand 2.0 page.
comments.author: JacobRusso

comments.text: I would like to print and assemble a Flextensor, and I'm wondering what non-printed parts I will need to complete the assembly.
comments.author: acblank

comments.text: The flexor cables are held into the large block, one string per hole, five set screws. The extensor cables all run through a single hole, at the end of the pivot, held in with a single set screw. The mechanism cover takes two very small screws. The cable guide has holes for four screws, but you can get away with two. Then the wrist hinge needs two large flat-head screws and matching nylock nuts. You need to string it with very strong cables; I use 250lb braided fishing line. Good luck, and stay in touch.
comments.author: acblank

description.text: A variable pitch rotor is used when the rotation speed stays constant, and the thrust needs to be changed. It is often used on helicopters and ship propellers. This model demonstrates the principle in a simple mechanism. Some gifs of the movement can be found here: http://imgur.com/gallery/3Y5kr If you enjoy my work, I would appreciate a small bitcoin donation to 1MSachsBbZJjBg83nEsTv95oLuQmnmZnGu.

Print each part according to the number (#) of times given in the filename (..._x #).  
Assemble using screws (30mm and 40mm long are recommended).

comments.text: may i use this variable center design/ i want to make a variable windmill design. i will remake the propellers to get better efficiency much larger also. in the end i want a energy producing wind generator it will use this variable pitch and a algorithm to pitch the props at the best angle for the wind speed thus keeping it making a consistent constant power. my son is going to make the code algorithm for me i will just design the wind generator.  thanks for sharing!

comments.text: If its spun fast enough it will create some thrust and noticeable difference between different pitches, however because of the weight and not aerodynamically optimized design, it will not be useful for anything else but a basic educational demonstration of the principle.

I made this because I was unsatisfied with the available choices for spool holders that could be made within the Simple's small build volume. It's a work in progress, but it gets the job done currently.
Edit: I have now changed out the STLs with a second version that should work better, and without any glue. Hopefully these work better with everyone--I'm pretty happy with how it's working so far. Instructions have been updated.
For reference, this was designed for a Push Plastic spool. It measures about 72mm in width.

Print two copies each of "Foot" and "Foot 2." Print one "Connector." The axles on each foot have a little cap that's been drafted out a small angle to help retain the bearing once it's set in place (note that this will make it more difficult to remove). I recommend having some tools or a solid flat surface to use when popping the bearings on. Print the feet as shown in the picture. The orientation is important, since you don't want any support structures cluttering up the interface between the Foot and Connector. You will need supports underneath the axles, but those are easy enough to tear out with some pliers. Once all the pieces are done, you should be able to press them snugly together. Any 608 bearings should work fine--I salvaged these off of an old skateboard.

comments.text: i have the 1405 model and already use a few of your mods. Thank you for making a spool holder that works for the small print volume!
comments.author: DMC3d_and_more

comments.text: I've been looking for a spool holder that works on my simple!  You rock!  Will let you know how it goes.  My bearings are 608zz, hope they fit!
comments.author: alejandrow

comments.text: I made the connector piece to fit the width the spool I was using at the time. If the one you print does not fit, we can try adjusting the model so that it will fit whatever you're using :)
comments.author: alejandrow

comments.text: Nice! There are not very many designers that think of us 4" builders :)
comments.author: alexhb

comments.text: Thanks! I am one of you, after all :D it's still a bit rudimentary, but hopefully I'll have time to push out something a little more robust soon. The connections that are "parallel" to the spool's directions are currently weak spots that I want to strengthen or eliminate altogether.
comments.author: alexhb

comments.text: Could I ask where you got your bearings? I found a few but at $10 a piece they're a little much!
comments.author: roijeric

comments.text: The ones I used are old skateboard bearings. I believe they were $15 for a pack of 8. You can probably go to any toy store that sells skateboards and find some bearings that will work just fine. For this purpose I wouldn't go for anything fancy.

Here is a simple crossbow that can shoot matches. All design credits go to Vince Iacovelli, I am just posting it.
EDIT 8/7/14: Added the STL of the metric file (in mm)

Use two hair clips and glue them between the small plastic pieces with the groove facing up. Wrap wire around the ends of the small plastic pieces as shown in the picture. Attach a string to the tips of the hair clips.
When finished, draw the string back to the notch and lay a match on top of the cut-out.Lift string up to fire.
Picture shows wrist strap taped to the handle for comfort.

A roosting bar mount for chickens. I guess you could use it as a towel rack, but fluffy chickens are so much more interesting than a fluffy towel.

1) Print two copies
2) Use hardware screws to attach to wall
3) Zip-tie bar in place

comments.text: Cute chickens! I had a couple dozen hens, I have a quaker parrot now. They all get funky when the light dims. They need a roost (a stick is fine, like you made) and some quiet (cover and privacy) and they are happy til morning.
comments.author: rogertheriault

comments.text:
Nice! Going to make one for my pen of black-breasted-red old english.
Your birds look a lot like my yokohama when she was young - What breed are they?
comments.author: alexhb

comments.text: Boring ol' leghorns. I got them on a whim while I was picking up some circuit boards in penn. They should be laying eggs sometime in October.
comments.author: alexhb

comments.text: They may be boring but they'll chugg out eggs like mad! I've got 6 leghorns for eggs right now and I've gotten 6 eggs a day for the past 3 years... and they're still going
comments.author: CopabX

comments.text: That's what I've heard. I also heard that they're really skittish but really smart. I've got one (black legband) that is really docile but the others always run out of the coop like it's a prison break every time the door is opened.
comments.author: alexhb

comments.text: Yeah, mine are pretty crazy. The calmest birds I've ever had were Red Stars, a sex-linked layer breed. They produced pretty well with HUGE brown eggs, and were very calm to pick up be around. Used to let them outside during the day with no fence and they'd come back to roost before sunset! You can't say that chickens are dumb, that's for sure
comments.author: CopabX

comments.text: I had to teach mine to roost by putting one on the bar and then pointing her out to the other three. Eventually they figured out to roost on the bar and not the windows (which flip open). I dunno about yours but mine seem like retards.
comments.author: alexhb

description.text:
This was designed like the marble catch I made to fit the Quadrilla marble run sets. This is a simple support "foot" that makes it much easier to set this up in rooms with thick carpet. (sometimes the farther away this toy is the better :)   
Printed it with 10-15% fill and 2 shells.

comments.text: So happy to happen upon this item. Coincidentally, my son just got our new 3D printer set up in his room with thick carpet. The elaborate Quadrilla marble run that he and I set up weeks ago finally fell when his friend accidentally bumped it. We have always wanted something like this. Thank you!!!
comments.author: AnnG

comments.text: Hi Ann, I'm glad you like it. It's an easy print and works remarkably well. I was considering making other parts for it (other than the marble collector I posted), but nobody seems to print this stuff. (well they haven't shared anything).
comments.author: AnnG
